I prefered /Dysfunctional Systems: Learning to Manage Chaos/ as a first dip into visual novels... the interface is linear as befits a plot-driven short story and the writing is funny and genuinely good"

As a fan of Christine Love's work (Digital: A Love Story, Don't Take it Personally, Babe) I appreciate the unique themes she tackles, especially concerning that of technology. Analogue: A Hate Story doesn't disappoint- it touches on many mature themes such as sexism, homosexuality, and more. It also paints a unique picture of an ancient fuedal-like society aboard a sci-fi space station, meshing the old with the new. The writing is spot-on and makes for a great read.
That is, if you like reading- this is a really simple sort of novel in that there is little to no scenery change, and only a decent amount of interaction. Additionally the user interface is not the easiest to get used to, mainly the command console- you will very likely at some point seek a guide for the command you'd like to use for a certain section. Otherwise the UI is fine, if plain- take a look at the screenshots, as it's what the entire game looks like.

Aside from those very minor gripes, if you get this game you're in for some great and thoughtful reading. It's a great story, and will take more than one playthrough to really understand and see everything.

The art style is very pleasing, has a very interesting plot, and is very well made with an amazing soundtrack. It's very addicting and even if you don't enjoy many visual novels, this one is different from most visual novels in general.

Analogue: A Hate Story is a intense visual-novel that leaves your jaw on the floor every minute. The story behind it is very strong and will easily get you attached to characters and your relationships with them. No matter what you think of your character or how they have acted through the remainder of the game, you still feel pity for them because you felt a connection to them. It does feature some contient that is very mature, which is the only downside to this game. Overall though, the story, characters, and interactivity of the novel is all easily balanced and is always making you want more, even after you complete it.

If you're looking for a light hearted VN, Analogue: A Hate Story is not it. Both because it's really light on the visual part and quite dark and heavy in the novel part. After finishing it, I felt glad about being back here, down on the ol' Earth.

The replayability value of this game, however, is quite low, if you're after the multiple ending achievements you're really likely to just click through the game from an existing save/beginning.
Another problem I had was the resolution - I was forced to lower the resolution of my Mac to get it to run properly.

Overall - if you enjoy the genre and darker themes, don't expect lots of fanservice and can find it on sale somewhere - go for it. Otherwise - don't bother.

This is a game where you do nothing but read logs. Diaries and letters of people long dead.
Of the drama they had in their lives.

Soooo... WHY DO I LOVE IT SO MUCH? I don't know!
Seriously, this game is amazing. Just be prepared that it has absolutely nothing in it except reading logs.
This game made me so morally and emotionally conflicted! Which is what makes this game great.

A well-written and thought-provoking visual novel about the fate of a failed generation ship, told through letters and log entries of some of its inhabitants. It relies heavily on  the different characters having very different perspectives on events, coupled with deliberate values dissonance to get its point across. It's a tragic and often disturbing story, and if you like visual novels, I recommend giving it a look.

It's a good story but has low replay value.

It's not for everyone as the gameplay is really limited.

I like the unique concept and setting though.

I'm not a big textwall fan though and I really wish they have a better way to streamline all this reading.

Music is nice I suppose.

6.5/10 Wait for a sale.

reviewText:
It makes an ingenious choice in placing the player in a role which fits into gameplay mechanics of many visual novel games, which is just reading a lot of text. You’re working remotely to uncover the final hours of spaceship wreckage by digging into its history log.

As a visual novel game, it only has a few branches in the story, which isn’t all too impressive. The branching point only determines who you’ll end up with at very late game. It has a pseudo-command prompt game to break out of the monotony of reading history logs.

As for the story, it provides a social commentary on gender issues and politics on a personal level in forms of diary entries. It doesn't really have a lot of hidden story which requires multiple playthroughs, and mainly sticks to one main story for the majority of the game.

Overall, it is a good place to start exploring visual novel games, without being all too complicated with the decision trees. But on the flipside, lacks replayablity by having very little deviants on the story branches.

A great example of diegetic storytelling.  Analogue: A Hate Story  is a game where you, a freelance investigator, delve into the archives of a long lost spaceship in an attempt to uncover the mystery behind it. Throughout this task, you recieve the help and company of the ship's two AIs, each with their unique personality. I strongly recommend this game for anyone interested in a short (2-3 hour) story filled with mystery, despair, loneliness, and love. Be prepared, however, as the game focusess heavily on reading. Do not expect much action, although there is a certain point in the game that will keep you on your toes, so don't be too relaxed either. There are 5 different endings, and different choices to make throughout the game, so it definitely has some replay value.\n\n9/10 for a good short game with likable characters and a heart-warming(and wrenching) story. If you liked this, I would recommend playing  Gone Home , or vice versa, as I found they were both similar in many aspects.

reviewText:
Analogue: A Hate Story is an interactive novel where you have to find out why a spaceship filled with colonists is now floating in space devoid of life. (The name is a play on a previous game, Digital: A Love Story.) As you read the various logs, you also discuss them with the ship's two AIs to get the full picture.

(This is all from the early part of the story to avoid spoilers. If you don't want to see story, skip this paragraph.) The story that unravels revolves around a sick young girl in a culture much like modern Korea who is placed in a stasis pod in hopes that future technology can cure her. She is instead woken up far in the future where culture has actually regressed several centuries, and not only can they not cure her, but they instantly arrange a marriage against her will to gain status for the family.

This is a very sad story, but powerful and worth reading. It's not for kids, though.

There's not a ton of gameplay here to judge. The music is pretty nice, and the soundtrack isn't a bad purchase. Ultimately, the value of this game hangs entirely on its story, and if you're not interested in reading it, then this game has nothing for you. If you're okay with delving into the story for a few hours, then you may find a lot to enjoy. It's definitely worth getting on sale if it sounds interesting to you.
The story is amazing. This visual novel can be very confusing at start, but once you figure how it works, it shows you the true meaning of hate.

It's a touching story that should be read.

I think I can count on my cat's remaining legs the number of times a I've played a game and felt such a powerful emotional and psychological attachment to the story and characters where I found myself  so deeply invested in every single moment . They felt so, so alive...even though you know from the start that everyone on board the ship has been dead for centuries. Analogue will rip at your heartstrings in one moment, then make you fall out of your chair laughing in another. It will force you to make decisions you will hate yourself for, and then console you immediately afterwards. This game invites YOU to become the author of your own narrative and as you slowly begin to uncover the truth of the Mugunghwa and her crew, you may find yourself doing some soul searching of your own.

It should also be said that Isaac Schankler's musical tracks do a superb job of complementing the pace and mood of this game, probably one of the few game soundtracks I've bought rather than downloaded off of youtube.

10/10

There's also a very clever bit where you have to figure out some console commands in-game. I got a definite feeling of accomplishment in completing that section.

If you don't like reading, this game isn't for you. I'd also question why you read this review.
If you do like reading, though, then I definitely recommend Analogue: A Hate Story.

P.S. The harem ending is canon. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise.
why is this in my library?

Analogue: A Hate Story

Lets cut straight to the chase.

- Gameplay -
The basic gameplay outside of the standard visual novel parts consists of using the ships main system, which is sort of like coding but actually fun, and searching through the ships various documents, trying to uncover the story behind the mysterious ship you've set out to explore. The actual visual novel elements are solid, giving you plenty of room to make different choices which heavily affect your relations with the ships two main AI's- Hyun-ae, and Mute.

- Characters -
This might fall short, considering there are only three actual characters in the game, including yourself. However, I found the ships two AI's to be both unique and well written, each in their own way. I can't say much for Mute herself, as I went with Hyun-ae's route, however the limited dialogue I had with her was... Well, certainly interesting. As for Hyun-ae, she happens to be my favorite part of the game, being extremely likable and interesting right from the start.

- Story -
The story is sort of in the backround, but no less involving and important. As I mentioned before, you uncover most of it through the ships various documents, and through talking with both the ships AI's. It seems to be a take on a post-apocalyptic (sort of?) take on japanese culture mixed with a lot of science fiction elements. Confusing, right? Nonetheless, it tells a surprisingly human and very thought provoking story, on morales, cultures, and general humanity as a whole.

- Final thoughts -
Overall, I had a lot of fun with this game, dispite it being a bit short (about four hours, but I'm a fast reader), it tells a compelling story, has some great characters, and is overall a generally good experience. Definately would recommend.

***9.5/10***
플레이타임 1시간

Wow, This game suprised me, it went beyond my expectations.Although I usaualy ignore and make fun of visual novels, this one just changed everything. Eventhough I started this as a joke run through, I eventually got hooked and started reading  the logs. Its characters and visual appeal is great, everything about this game is great. Although I know  nothing of visual novels one thing I do know is that this game was worth the buy. I highly recomend this game expecially when its on sale. I highly encourage you even if you've never played a Visual Novel, to buy this game

This game... this game and its sequel are fantastic. Basically all of Christine Love's work is, but these are just amazing.


I actually like Hate Plus more in some ways and Analogue more in others. So I'm torn as far as which is better, but I can safely say that they were both well worth the effort. I have like 4 hours on this game, but I actually played it through multiple times--I read insanely fast--and can safely say that I'm glad I did so.

Writing: Best part, honestly. Love's writing is able to be expressive and emotional with ease. Characters have their own voices, their own personalities--and with this many characters, you better believe that's a feat. Nothing is over wrought or underwritten. This is an episolatory Visual Novel, and it works.


Graphics stuff: I liked the interface. The console part was the least impressive, and some people might find it rather hard to believe considering the advanced tech--though keep in mind that the ship is only a few hundred years ahead of us in its origin--but its a callback to Love's earlier freeware game, Digital: A Love Story and reminded me a bit of the Amie interface. The two AIs are Animu waifu material. No way around that. The art is good quality, though, and their expressions are both endearing and rather genuinely funny. Mute's a bit more expressive, but that fits the character.


Music: It's good! However, it's far from amazing. Digital: A Love Story's soundtrack was PERFECT and I want it rather badly--Analogue and Hate Plus's is decent and I wouldn't mind paying a few bucks for it. There were a lot of good chances to use music to set scenes that were passed up.


All in all? 10/10. Yes, it's not perfect, but a 10 isn't for perfection. It's for games that leave me either thirsty for more ad infinitum or games that after I play them I turn the computer off, stumble into bed, and think lots of big, scary thoughts. This game and its sequel do both.


Try it. It's only $10.


(Also, if you're still unsure, try Digital: A Love Story and Don't Take it Personal
recommended: it just ain't your story" which are both free and by the same person.)"

reviewText: I like this game somewhat, but I'm guessing that the majority of people would get bored with it, find it confusing, or something. Not recommended unless you know what you're getting.

Oh man, what can I say about this game/book/thing?
Other than that I picked it up on a whim (it was on sale, and sci-fi and cute girls and things are always nice, lol), finally got around to playing it last night (or, more accurately, this morning), and played it through in one sitting- bathroom breaks notwithstanding, of course.

It's just...
it's so good. SO GOOD.

PLAY/READ THIS GAME/BOOK.
DO IT.
Something different.  If you like reading then this is definitely worth trying out.

Hyun-ae, do I love thee, oh let me count the ways...
Analogue doesn't quite fit 'visual novel' as a category, but that's the closest name we've got. Because what Analogue really is, is a multi-faceted adventure story that you, the protaganist, can only read about - except of course, when it comes to life around you in the form of a ship's AI who was there at the time. The two AI, Hyun-ae and Mute, are gorgeous in their differences, and humorous in comparison, one showing somethings while hiding others and vice versa. And it's a good thing you've got these two (ONLY two? In a VN? But but... yeah. This is no ero story :P) chirpy and/or eager-to-please starbabes to guide you through the diaries of  the Mugungwe's last days because... Everyone will read something different into the historical world created, into the character of the Pale Bride, and into how everything comes to a conclusion. I, for one, fell helplessly in love with a fake AI in a game... so there's that.

However you choose to enjoy the game, as an explorer, as a route seeker, as a completionist, there are hours of... entertainment, I won't always say enjoyment. Some messages are uncomfortable to hear and Christina Love does, once again, a wonderful job of giving us a rude awakening to things we might rather ignore.

Read like a novel, this is harrowing and heartfelt. Read in role-play, truly reacting to and feeling with Hyun-ae... it'll darn near break your heart. All the recommends.

Now, there are a lot of reviews floating around complaining about how the game 'doesn't feel like a visual novel', or asking why there are only so many 'routes' and 'endings'. Those people are, I think, completely missing the point of Analogue: A Hate Story. It's not a dating sim. Sure, there are elements of that format, and you do have the ability to manipulate the story somewhat through your responses. However, this game is more of a visual novel in the purest sense: it invites you to uncover a story. Apparently there's 59,000 words of text in this game, so if you're feeling unfulfilled by finishing subsequent playthroughs within ten minutes like one of the top-rated negative reviewers, you're doing it wrong.\n\nTo be fair, Analogue is a short game. There's not a huge amount to it, and it doesn't take a significant time investment to complete. However, what is there is charming and thought-provoking, with a surprisingly interesting - if slightly two-dimensional - story to be dug through. I'm sure if you were to put the game into Skip Mode, you probably could get the best ending in ten minutes, but you'd be totally missing the point. Experience this game as if it were a book, for after all, that is what a good visual novel is intended to emulate.

This game tells a very good story.  A very screwed up one,  with equally damaged characters, but very well done.  If you like visual novel style games, give Analogue:   A Hate Story a shot.  If you've never tried one before, then at least try the demo.

This game falls into a catagory of games most westerners arn't familiar with: Visual Novels. Its essentially one giant anime cutscene with dialogue choices and some digging through files to unearth what happened to a ship that vanished over 600 years ago, and has recently been rediscovered. It is extremely well written and I would highly reccomend it. Hit me up if you enjoy it for other Visual Novel reccomendations.

Analogue: A Hate Story is a well written visual novel game.

Something I liked was all dating or relationship aspects, typically found in a visual novel, are minor aspects of the game. The story focused on the journey of discovery of what caused the fate that befell the generational colony ship.

Hate Plus was relased after Analogue and is a prequil. They can be played independtly of each other.

Not the best Visual Novel I've ever played, but not terrible.

The graphics are simple, which doesn't bother me.

What does bother me is how simplistic the story is. The interlinking is done well, but the story seems hyperbolic, possibly due to unreliable narrators, but without hanging a lantern on this fact.

But, even still, I enjoyed it. I wouldn't have felt I got my purchase price worth, however, had I not gotten it on sale.
Save some A.I.'s with your Mad Hacks and Reading Comprehension. Also Korean history and a ship name that is hard to say. :D

Less of a game, more of an interactive story. A few timed events, choices matter, honestly better than some of the top of the line games I've played. It's got a great story with two polar opposite characters, not including you, two plays the semi-silent protagonist which follows what ever attitude you feel like having at the moment. It's quick, at times cute, at times sad, but always fun, when you know what you're doing.

This game has the type of gameplay similar to that of detective work, where you sort through various logs in order to put a story together piece by piece. It was a lot of reading, but it was certainly worth unraveling the mystery. Aside from that, I enjoyed the different personalities of the characters as well as their art styles.
Not bad.\n\nRevealed my poor typing skills. If it is on sale, pick it op.

Amazingly interesting game. Quite engrossing - you'll lose time as you play old-school detective.

And I don't mean old school detective as in noire or gumshoe, I mean detective as in analyzing a given set of data and slowly building the puzzle from a finite resource.

Great fun, better than expected. You almost don't feel the rails.
The story was a little hard to follow until I had more pieces, but the AI characters really bring the whole game together.  A rather fun Indi game that I'll likely play again some time soon.
I picked this up on a whim and was blown away at how unique and creative the story was. I'd advise, though, if you get this to get the sequel : Hate Plus. +1
Was significantly better than I expected. Hyun-ae pretty solid waifu.

Before you go any further, a primer: This is a game that is designed to be finished like a book. It is not one where you pit your -supposed- skills against computer- or human-controlled opponents. It offers a fairly refreshing twist to the way stories are normally told.

First off, let me say upfront that if action is all that matters to you (and/or you're not a fan of visual novels), don't even bother looking at this game - you're entirely incompatible with it and simply won't think much of it, so save yourself time and don't bother with the demo (or reading the rest of this review). In fact, the screenshots on the game's page are all you will ever see in the game, the rest is up to your imagination. You won't see the Mugunghwa or its interior, nor your own ship's. There is no voice acting, and all you will ever interact with are two AI individuals, and an override terminal through which you can switch between the two and perform some other tasks.

However, if you are willing to look beyond that, the storyline is actually pretty interesting. It's really hard to explain it without spoiling anything, and I think the description on the game's page does a fairly good job of explaining the context. I recommend giving the demo a go, it's well worth your time if you're willing to look deeper than the seemingly simple first impression - I was already captivated by the storyline in the demo, and so much so that it successfully persuaded me to get the full game.

Unfortunately, if you're still unfamiliar with the names, the questions the AI occasionally asks of your opinion will sometimes catch you off guard as you struggle to recall who they're talking about, and the inability to refer to the family tree at that juncture only serves to compound the problem.

At some point in the game, the override terminal will temporarily become an integral part of your story, so don't forget how to use it (although it should be easy to figure out how). It would be nice if it supported tabbed commands (i.e. pressing tab to autocomplete partially entered commands) and command history (i.e. using the up and down cursor keys to speed up entry of repeated commands) just like its real life counterparts, since at the abovementioned point in the game, you'll find yourself typing largely the same commands over and over.

All in all, a piece well worthy of your time.

Very well written, and has some intriguing game concepts in regards to how you can make a Virtual Novel more interactive.  Imagine reading a book and having to coax the writer to reveal more of the true story!  Impossible for fiction, but in a game/VN it fits perfectly.  It took me two hours to finish and I imagine if I wanted to see all the endings and extras (the game keeps track of all em), it would take me an additional hour and a half.
Very unique and interesting. Strong, mature themes. Unique setting. Recommended!
Surprisingly in depth and touching storyline with a hint of sadness and severe sexism experienced with the characters within the story.... Well done to the makers!

It's a book. Kind of. The way that the story is presented is interesting and even though it's not so much a 'game' as it is a 'textwall' broken up by bits of dialogue the story itself is engaging and continues to throw in little surprises even though you're working from the end backward.
For a game where you just read a bunch of dead guys diaries, its kind of brilliant.
Christine Love doesn't disappoint, she travels to uncharted territory and finds gold, every single time.
There should be more games/VisualNovels like this on here - such a great story, I can definitely recommend this one (as well as Hate Plus).

If you don't like long reviews, I'll just claim that this game is simply awesome.
If you want to know why I wrote that, I'll explain.
The game sets an unknown character -the player- is sent to a long-lost space ship, the Mugunghwa, to discover what happened there. On the Mugunghwa you find two AI's in charge of the logs of the ship. The gameplay is pretty simple, read the logs, show them to the AI's so they can help you find more, and repeat until you are satisfied. Maybe you can get one of the AI's back home, maybe not, or maybe both.
But what makes this so amazing is the backstory behind the Mugunghwa, its people and its tragic conclusion. Saying anything about that would be considered spoiler, so if you want to know what happened, either buy this, try the demo to catch a glimpse, or get spoiled somewhere else, I'm not talking anymore about the heartbreaking story.

reviewText: Overall great game if you're into Text Based Adventures. Cool story with multiple endings that all led to very different conclusions. I'd give it a 7 out of 10, but most are likely to give it lower due to the style of play.\n

A fascinating interactive story about the devolution of a society in the wake of an unknown disaster.  While I find it hard to believe people could regress so specificly into a society that embodies only the worst and few of the good traits of the Joseon Dynasty period of Korea's history, I soon forgot this minor nitpick as I became engaged in the lives of the various individuals and the interaction with the two AIs.  I look forward to learning the truth about the disaster that brought tragedy and ruin apon the crew of the Mugunghwa.
for people looking for an interesting interactive story, look no further. unless you already got hate plus. then you should play this first. yes.
This game is worth the money and exteremly fun! Get it if you get the chance.
Dramatic and so full of those small details that make it seem alive. Love the characters, love the story - everything is exactly where it need to be... drama, passion, romance, grief
Analoge Is a moving story of people, politics, society and love.\nBeautiful and moving, a novel you can take at your own pace.
I am pretty sure my job was to download logs, but all I did was make a virtual waifu
It's a mystery that pulls you deeper as you go along. I really enjoyed it! This is my first game that's like this, but I've already bought the next one.

If you are a fan of visual novels this is definitely a must-play. For it's short 5 hours of gameplay it manages to deliver a fantastic storyline. And if you are new to these types of games it's a great introduction to the genre of visual novels without having to play with the volume on low while making sure no one is watching you behind your back. (Ahem)
Amazing use of genre and medium

Surprisingly a good Visual Novel. While the two main characters are somewhat interesting (though, I swear, *Mute's 'men are superior' lines kept getting to me!) there are a plethora of other characters to get to know. Kind of. I mean, you are on a derelict ship, reading old log files, but the sordid history of the families and the long-dead people on the ship are interesting. A little hard remembering the names, especially if you don't speak korean (or like most western audiences, are used to Firstname Surname formatting of names)

All in all, a pretty good story, and I have been going through it trying to unlock all the logs (which thankfully accumulate through play throughs, as I am not sure it is possible to do in one game)

Only thing I wish this game had… was badges and cards. I mean, seriously, where are my badges and cards?

It's about as subtle as a brick to the face but I think the message was well executed. Also does some interesting things with the format of the visual novel, mostly in the form of explaining how that form of interaction could actually make sense. One section in particular really stands out as a great meeting of mechanics and story. Worth playing as a curiosity, but be warned. It doesn't play nice.

Interesting story that kept me guessing to the end. Easy to play and relax for a bit. Some of the log entries were heart-breaking. All of them very well written. Despite the very difficult (Korean) names, in the end you did get to relate to the characters and felt sorry for them. Great short game if you're looking for immersion. It's only text-based. No action.
One of the best ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ VNs I've ever played, knocked out of the freaking PARK by Christina Love (sp?)
Super sweet visual novel. If you like games with awesome narratives, I would check this out.
For a dating sim type game this is quite good.  It is sorta like researching an old korean drama very compelling

Interesting little game, even though it is definitely a niche sort of experience, since it involves a lot of reading. While the story is average, the characters and some their reactions to the messages are quite charming.

If you're reading this on Valentine's day weekend, pick it up now, it's only $2 and it's amazing. If you're not, you should pick it up anyway, or be lame and wait for a sale. Either way, Analogue: A Hate Story is a game that on paper sounds terribly boring, and yet it is one of the deepest games I've played, and kept me hooked an entire weekend. In this game, you are not important. You are investigating the sudden reappearance of a long lost colony space ship. Hundreds of years later, it's entire crew is dead. The only intelligent being left is a very lonely AI, who you encounter when attempting to access the ship's mainframe. With her help, you investigate the ship's logs, and peer into the inner most thoughts of the ship's occupants. It's amazing how Cristine Love brings them to life. It starts innocent enough in attempting to solve the mystery of the ship's access codes, but then becomes a mystery: What happened to the ship's occupants turns into Who is the Pale Bride, and what happened to her? Then, your heart breaks. I highly, highly recommend that you try this game. If you've ever enjoyed a visual novel or an adventure game, there's a good chance you'll love it as much as I did. Christine Love is a master of story telling.

At first when I started playing this game, I was very dissapointed with the way the game progress by just reading message after message. I thought it would be like Japanese Visual Novel. Nevertheless, I gave this game a chance, and start interacting with the AI and read the message on and on.

And guess what, I got sucked in so deep to the story it unfolded--the way these message presented its novel, it just makes me hunger to find out the truth. Different AI provided different point of view and revealing different story and scandal. I must take it all back that I feel dissaponted with this game.

This game is really good, with highly addictive story in the form of message and interactive AI. Yes, it is different from the normal Japanese Visual Novel, but different doesn't mean this game is not enjoyable.

If you love a good story filled with emotional torrents, and two cute AI to interact with, then give this game a chance. Trying playing its demo first if you must. And in the end, I guaranteed you that you will get addicted to the story that you cannot stop playing... it's like you need to keep on going for the desires of finding out the truth of what really happened on that spaceship.
This is a reading game :) If you love reading, then this is for you.

Recommended if you enjoyed those ancient dos games where you'd have to type in Linux-like commands to figure out how to solve problems. A lot of it is TL:DR (Too Long Didn't Read) but if that's your thing, then - why not. Got it for 80% percent off.. Don't buy it at full price - at $1.99 for maybe 3 hours of reading, why not.
Mindbreak trap. (~@A@)~

I just can recommend this game, its wonderful written and left a deep impression to me. The story is very good executed and has its share of twists (and i don't mean some B-movie twists or some Deus ex machina (not the game the twist type) but some that make really sense while being shocking and really affect your view of the characters.)

This title was particularly surprising to me.
So far I've only had the chance to play through one ending, however, even that has made me want to play the sequel, in fact, as soon as I'm done typing this, it's going to the top of my wishlist.

I have little experience with visual novels, so I'm not in any position to compare it to others. However, based on novel, and games, and any other form of story-telling, this game holds it's own. To me, it feels like uncovering the lost lore of the fallout universe, paired with a rather well done romance system, that leaves you wanting to play the game until you've gotten every ending.

*very minor spoilers*

The story begins with you being told to go investigate the wreckage of a ship, and download as many data logs as you can find. When you go to access the main console, you are told that you need a password to be given administrator access in order to download them. However, even after finding the password, you're not going to download the files and leave. The AI commentary, and the story behind the ship being wrecked are absolutely rivoting, and at the end, you'll find yourself a little depressed if you didn't find %100 of the ship's logs. So, even though I got this game on sale, I would have paid full price for this game in a heartbeat if I knew it was this incredible.

If you like visual novels, then buy it, and never regret it.

This game has been out for a while and I don't know who else would still buy it so I'll keep it as short as possible. I haven't played the game too much to get all of the endings yet but I have beaten it once. The game by far is an interesting story filled with a heavy amount of sadness and almost no happy points. Of course messing with the AI's is fun. I enjoyed the story to the point that I will go back and play and get the rest of the endings. I'll suggest that those who enjoy a good dramatic story pick this game up. Especially if it's on sale.
I've never been rendered as speechless by a game as I did by this one when the last pieces of the puzzle finally came together.\n\nBrilliantly disturbing.

Truly an intriguing story and a game that requires a few playthroughs to get the full experience.  I absolutely loved it and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys narrative games.\n\nI really liked the interface and graphics as well.  Topnotch game!
Quite a change to see a non-Japanese VN. A good story, 2 very lovable AIs, great music. Reading the logs may become boring to some, but push through it to learn the whole story of *Hyun-ae.

This is a very well developed game. It has a very smooth interface and the background music did not get on my nerves no matter how much it played. The story is not hard to follow and it is very well paced. I would recommend this to anyone who likes the visual novel genre.

Most of this game is reading through text logs in order to understand what happened on an abandoned ship.  What you find is a deep story that makes you feel for the characters.  It is not a terribly long game; my first run through was under 3 hours, but it is was a worthwhile experience.

I really fell in love with the unique style of storytelling and character growth. The game has you gradually exploring and expanding on the experiences of those long past to uncover a startling mystery. The characters in the game each have a unique and very distinctive personality. Once I picked it up, I couldnt put it down- luckily a full playthrough is only about 2-3 hours.

Look, this is a visual novel. It's also a cyber-archaeological window into a neo-confuscianist korean spaceship society. It's also a character study with themes of family and gender roles. It has multiple endings, and you ought to get all of them. The sequel is also excellent, but this one stands alone.\n\ntl;dr - Analogue is an utterly capitvating novel. Buy it.
I know visual novel games aren't for everyone, but this is a really engaging sci-fi story with some interesting twists. Lots of interesting reading to do and fun characters to interact with!

I was a bit leery of the whole 'visual novel' aspect of the game, but after receiving it as part of an indie bundle, I decided to try it out. While rather short - about five hours - I thoroughly enjoyed it. It gets rather emotional, and even more so if you allow yourself to be immersed into the setting. It took me a while to make sense of everything - probably about half an hour - but once you understand who all of the major players are, and start to grasp the setting, things really get awesome.

Sadly, the emotional impact was diminished quite a bit whilst trying to achieve the alternate endings. Going over documents I had already read just wasn't quite as stimulating as the first time, although ocassionally I'd stumble over new content that would make me laugh (or cry, as it were).

Anyway, if you like the concept of video games as art, I think you'll absolutely love this game. If you expect any sort of action, then look elsewhere. This game is very slow-paced (as it should be).
There is a lot of reading to this, and not much of an ending.. but that would be missing the point. Part dating sim, part space mystery, this is a neat little visual novella game.

Like Christine Love's earlier game Digital: a Love Story, Analogue feels like a detective story while still conveying a very compelling message about society and human relationships. The game's simulated computer interface gives the player a sense of both power and isolation, but the limited flow of information leaves you wanting more of the story, even after reading a novel's worth of log entries.

Christine Love does very interesting games, although they're more like Interactive Fiction than a 'game' - she uses the medium to tell stories that wouldn't really be possible without them. Analogue is something of a companion story to Digital: A Love Story, one of her earlier works.\n\nI really like Analogue. It is simple and basically consists of a lot of reading with a few simple puzzles to spice things up. It won't be for everyone but, really, you should try this game. It's a solid story that really tugged at my heartstrings. And the music is quite good as well.

Make no mistake, this IS a visual novel, which implies that 90% of this will be reading.

In particular, 90% of this will be reading about gender politics and self destruction in neo-feudal korea.

Anyway, to the 5 people with steam accounts I didn't scare away, I find it is well-written thus far, and I would recommend a look to anyone with the patience.

what can i say about this game... well for one, it was throughly entertaining, though a bit short. i loved the characters (all 2 of them) that i got to interact with. changing how they saw the world, and making them understand other view points that throughly satisfying. reading over what happened to the crew and seeing how it affected the two AI's was pretty fun to. i'd give it 8 out of 10. the game was short, but the writing was soild, the premise entertaining, and the art beautiful.
visual novel gaming!~!!~!

This is a real hidden gem of a game, and the sequel is even better. There are very limited choices when it comes to the visual novel genre on Steam, but this is well worth the find. You play as a lonely investigator sent into deep space to sort out the mystery of a ship in which the entire crew was murdered. It might sound like the plot of a horror game, but believe me it's nothing like that. You start out typing commands into a computer prompt, figuring out how to maneuver through the operating system. Later you'll come to meet the two remaining members of the ship: two AI girls known as Hyun-ae and Mute. The two have very different opinions on what happened; and their conflicting stories will add to your dilemma. You spend the rest of the game rather tediously sorting through encrypted ship logs one by one...the only boring part of the game, really. Reading each log is immensely interesting, though; like reading a rich novel filled with romance, political intrigue, drama and suspense. You will also interact with the girls a lot; who you believe, the choices you make, what logs you decide to show to them and how you answer your question will guide the story to it's conclusion. I don't want to give anything else away plot wise because the story is really THAT good. Christine Love is a genius, and this game is a breath of fresh air in the VN world.

While I don't usually play that many visual novels, I was extremely interested upon reading the premise of the story. And I was glad I did play it. The story was extremely interesting to read, even when I got the hang of who was who and what not. The only problem was me spending about an hour trying to figure out what to do after talking to the first AI and not knowing how to change  the personalities, a mistake on my part xD.\n\nRegardless though, the story is extremely interesting to read.

Analogue: A Hate Story was an interesting play, short but interesting. The main driving focus of the game is reading, so if you're not much for reading or don't like to slog through datalogs, I wouldn't recommend this, but to me it's more like a book with pictures and such, so, for what you get, it's pretty good.

Playing the sequel that tells you more about the story behind Analogue gets the game to seem even more interesting after having it played. Making the links between the characters and events throughout the two games is, I think, the best part of the whole series. I can only recommend Analogue if you'll be willing to pair it with its sequel as if it was a single game. Not because it wouldn't be a great experience on its own, but because the experience you get after learning everything there is to learn dwarfs it in comparison.

$10 is a bit steep, especialy when you get about 75% of the game in the demo, but for people who love to emerse yourselves and truly believe you are a part of the story, pick it up. I'm not dissapointed in the least.

reviewText: great story wonderful art worth the time

If you are looking for a game with great combat and cool looking weapons, you are in the wrong place. But if you are a fan of Anime or Manga, you cannot go past this. Its an interactive story filled with romance, comedy and drama. There are moments when it makes you laugh, but there are also those tragic tear jerker moments that leave you speechless. It is a fantastic story where you get to choose what happens next, you pick what happens in the story based on what appeals to you most at the time, and these choices have a big impact on the story down the road. I highly reccomend this to all Anime and Manga fans. Seriously, get it, its amazing.

Analogue is a pure visual novel, has little gameplay, and is a much more passive experience than Digital: A Love Story (which is free and I humbly suggest you play first).  Despite its multiple endings, Analogue is much more straigthforward than Digital; you should not be at a loss for what to do more than once or twice.  Also, the dialogue choices rarely matter beyond a given conversation.  I didn't see this as a problem as it adds much needed interaction with the characters, but it may conflict with your expectations.\nThe game is passive but not unengaging.  At the very least, the documented narratives should unsettle you but it is balanced with a decidedly less depressing and more interactive overarching story.  That being said, some story arcs are less interesting than others.\nI realize this kind of game doesn't appeal to everyone, but if it interests you I doubt it will disappoint.

Analogue's pacing was spot on as Christine Love continuously keeps the reader engaged in the story and the dialogue with the likeable AI heroines. The actual setting itself is highly plausible with believable journal entries and character interactions. There wasn't a moment where my suspension of disbelief was broken, allowing me to immerse myself into this enjoyable, albeit short, story.

The overall presentation was excellent; while it may be a superficial thing, I haven't seen a physical layout in a visual novel this aesthetically pleasing in a long time.

That being said, Analogue does leave something to be desired. While the entire tale is told in its entirely and its loose ends are cleaned up nicely, it left me feeling unfulfilled. At the end of the day, Analogue is less of a game and more of an interactive story. If you aren't the kind of person who enjoys reading, you're probably going to want to pass over this one. I would give this game a solid B+; I highly recommend it.

I can't say I'm much more visual novels, or that I've really had much experience with them outside the two I've read/played by Christinia Love (Digital: A Love Story, being the first one I read/played.)
And, well, I definitely would say to look into Digital: A Love Story since it's freeware and it's a very interesting execution of a visual novel that makes it feel much less like the very very tiny bit of other visual novels I've tried. It's also a bit more accesible than Analogue: A Hate Story, so in general it's a good place to start to see if you even like Love's style before spending money on a more involved and intense story.

Now, when I say Digital has a interesting execution, that isn't to say Analogue doesn't. It is similar in many ways, but it's different - which is good, really. The interface of both games fits the story and setting. Analogue does feel more like a visual novel, though. But probably because it's longer and there is quite a bit more reading. However, it's a complex story, and told in a way that is engaging. It also manages to deal with many serious themes. Patriatrcy, sexism, sexuality -- to name a few.

So, try Digital: A Love Story and if you like it, then chances this is a game for you (mind you, this is... well it is called A Hate Story"). Or

reviewText: I still haven't finished it completely as I write those lines, but I really think this novel is totally worth reading and the story is deepling moving, at least it's what I felt.\n\nSo if you like reading and want to try something a bit different from usual books, This novel is totally worth to be bought, especially for such a low price :)

Analogue is a visual novel with a lot of choose-your-own-adventure aspects and a touch of dating sim, maybe. In the game, you are investigating a generation ship that disappeared 600 years ago and has just been found. You’re tasked with finding out what happened by reading through the ship’s logs. The ship has two AI which can help you with your mission, though they aren’t particularly reliable narrators.

Gameplay mainly consists of reading through the ship’s logs and asking the AI about them, who may then open up new logs for you. The main interface for accessing the logs is slick, attractive, and very easy to use. There is also a Linux console interface which you use to perform certain actions on the ship, such as enabling or disabling the AI, or downloading the log files. As someone who has never used Linux I found this interface a bit puzzling at first. It’s the first thing you see when the game starts and it took me a few minutes to figure out what it was expecting me to do.

The most exceptional part of the game is the writing. The logs, written as diary entries are enthralling. There are multiple authors and each one has a clear and distinct voice. They paint a picture of a spacefaring society that has somehow regressed into a medieval patriarchy. You don’t get access to all the entries though, and often get things out of order, so you need to piece together the story for yourself. Depending on which AI you have active, you may learn some parts of the story but not others. It’s quite well done.

As for the interaction with the AI though… ehh. One AI is a giggly, cosplay-loving schoolgirl. The other is a casually misogynist and homophobic security program.  If I had known nothing about the creator of this game, Christine Love, I likely would have written the game off as sexist drivel and quit before I got too far in. However, I assumed that there was probably going to be a bigger point or message to the game, so I continued.

I haven’t played a ton of visual novels before, the most similar experience I’ve had to this was Long Live the Queen. An aspect of the genre I find hard to reconcile is that I want to see multiple endings, but the process of replaying and trying new things to get to those endings is exceedingly tedious. Careful use of saves can reduce the amount of repetition, but it’s hard to know exactly when the important branches take place and I find myself mindlessly clicking through things I’ve already read/seen way more than is enjoyable.

Verdict: Recommended for those who like the genre. The writing is strong and the story is compelling. While I personally don’t enjoy the repetitiveness required to experience all of the endings, I think this game will appeal to fans of visual novels.
Waifu Sim. Get up to 2 waifus at once.

This is a short visual novel in which you're a detective trying to ascertain what happened in a derelict spaceship hundred years ago. If you don't mind dark themes and aren't searching for a moe, cutesy story, you may very well love it: the plot is interesting and the characters complex and morally ambiguous.\n\nJust keep in mind that you'll have to dig through dozens of logs to unravel the truth (if you're wary of reading for hours, turn away) and the main themes are quite sad and disturbing. But sometimes sad and disturbing is the way to go.

This is one of the best visual novels I've ever played.

The premise is simple, yet compelling. You are a nameless, genderless, ageless space investigator sent to read the logs of the long-dead in order to understand what happened on board the generation ship, Mugunghwa. You do this with the assistances of two AI, *Hyun-ae, a young woman, and *Mute, the ship's security system. They are the powerful personalities that make this game worth playing, and if you're anything like me, you will fall in love with them both.

Warning: the logs deal with physical and emotional abuse aimed towards children. It also explores homophobia, speifically towards lesbians, misogyny and classism. Forgive me if I spelt any of those words wrong.

Analogue's gameplay is entirely text based. You will be reading log after log after log. Initially, the logs aren't that interesting, but very quickly, I was drawn into the game. The GUI is sleek and actually does feel like a futuristic computer. It's simple and easy to use, and it's unlikely you'll ever get lost. The most confusing it gets is when you need to prompt the AI to search for more logs by clicking on logs written by the particular person you wish to investigate.

(I hope that sentence made sense).

The real focus of this game is the AI, although Analogue focuses more on *Hyun-ae then *Mute. (*Mute's game is Hate Plus, the sequel to Analogue, which I also recommend you buy). I won't spoil anything, but through these women, you're confronted with some serious moral ambiguity. Actions and beliefs that are objectively terrible are rationalized, and suddenly you're not sure what to think.

The minor characters are basically every person you'll read about in the logs. They all serve their purpose; no-one is focused on so extensively that they over-shadow everyone else. Moreover, they all feel like real people. The logs are well written and feel genuine...although I do feel the lesbian sex between too women was written in more detail then strictly necessary.

Your choices matter in this game, btw, particular when you're finally given the option to stop being a genderless and ageless entity. Whether you select male or female will influnce one AI significantly.

Overall, this is a very good game. It's heart-felt, its well-written, its fascinating, and its cheap. Give Analogue a go, you won't regret it :)

I have very limited experience with visual novels - basically they're something cute that occasionally turn up in humble bundles that i buy. so i've played hatoful boyfriend, long live the queen, and now Analogue: A Hate Story.

Personally, I loved it. I was really sold on the main character, and deeply moved by the history that unfolded. YMMV as always but this game really made me feel the desperate sadness it was aiming for.

Analogue has a delightfully minimalist intro and u/i that really rewards effort on the player's part to discover the context for the story, so I would not recommend looking up any of the lore before you play - if you don't want to spend some time piecing it together for yourself then you won't enjoy the game anyways!

Hate Plus picks up right where this one lets off and opens the story up a lot more for both of our protaginists, so if you like this one, Get Hate Plus. The story is loads more immersive. If this is your first VN, it's not a bad start, as its not too much in the VN side and more into the storytelling side.

Protip: Come back to this one and play it again after Hate Plus, the story will piece together A LOT better this time.

This is a real hidden gem of a game, and the sequel is even better. There are very limited choices when it comes to the visual novel genre on Steam, but this is well worth the find. You play as a lonely investigator sent into deep space to sort out the mystery of a ship in which the entire crew was murdered. It might sound like the plot of a horror game, but believe me it's nothing like that. You start out typing commands into a computer prompt, figuring out how to maneuver through the operating system. Later you'll come to meet the two remaining members of the ship: two AI girls known as Hyun-ae and Mute. The two have very different opinions on what happened; and their conflicting stories will add to your dilemma. You spend the rest of the game rather tediously sorting through encrypted ship logs one by one...the only boring part of the game, really. Reading each log is immensely interesting, though; like reading a rich novel filled with romance, political intrigue, drama and suspense. You will also interact with the girls a lot; who you believe, the choices you make, what logs you decide to show to them and how you answer your question will guide the story to it's conclusion. I don't want to give anything else away plot wise because the story is really THAT good. Christine Love is a genius, and this game is a breath of fresh air in the VN world.

While I don't usually play that many visual novels, I was extremely interested upon reading the premise of the story. And I was glad I did play it. The story was extremely interesting to read, even when I got the hang of who was who and what not. The only problem was me spending about an hour trying to figure out what to do after talking to the first AI and not knowing how to change  the personalities, a mistake on my part xD.\n\nRegardless though, the story is extremely interesting to read.

Moving story, characters you can sympathise with, excellent soundtrack and wonderful art come together to make this one of the best visual novels I've played.  Recommended to anybody interested in the genre, and those who have an interest in Korean cultural history.  Now if only I could get over my love for *Hyun-ae enough to do *Mute's route...\n\n10/10

I think it is the only game I have ever got all the achievements for, so it is not a long or difficult game to complete...unless reading emails is a problem in which case I would advise against it as that is pretty much all there is to the game.

The console parts were a throwback to my days trying to get dos games to run on a PC that couldn't really handle them - curse you nostalgia!

I don't regret buying or playing it but it is not for everyone.

If you don't like reading, then this isn't the game for you.

But if you're the kind of person who, when they're playing any other sort of video game likes to read all the optional journal entries and log files of the departed denizens of whatever ruin you're slicin' up monsters in, then you'll find this a pleasant surprise.

The visual novel format does much to immerse you inside the game's world--you're not just a guy reading a book, you're a guy on a spaceship drifting next to an abandoned hulk reading the ship's logs about a doomed voyage while two AIs who aren't telling you the whole story comment on them.

It's not anime". It's a story about politics
recommended: and inhumanity. It's one of the first "visual novels" to remember that the word "novel" is there for a reason."

reviewText:
Analogue: A Hate Story is an interactive novel where you have to find out why a spaceship filled with colonists is now floating in space devoid of life. (The name is a play on a previous game, Digital: A Love Story.) As you read the various logs, you also discuss them with the ship's two AIs to get the full picture.

(This is all from the early part of the story to avoid spoilers. If you don't want to see story, skip this paragraph.) The story that unravels revolves around a sick young girl in a culture much like modern Korea who is placed in a stasis pod in hopes that future technology can cure her. She is instead woken up far in the future where culture has actually regressed several centuries, and not only can they not cure her, but they instantly arrange a marriage against her will to gain status for the family.

This is a very sad story, but powerful and worth reading. It's not for kids, though.

There's not a ton of gameplay here to judge. The music is pretty nice, and the soundtrack isn't a bad purchase. Ultimately, the value of this game hangs entirely on its story, and if you're not interested in reading it, then this game has nothing for you. If you're okay with delving into the story for a few hours, then you may find a lot to enjoy. It's definitely worth getting on sale if it sounds interesting to you.

Christina Vee is probably the best writer of visual novels in the English-speaking world, and Analogue continues that tradition via an engaging and thought-provoking storyline, delivered in an extremely immersive fashion. I strongly this (and it's spiritual predecessor, Digital: A Love Story" to anyone interested in the genre."

This game tried to win me over but couldn't, but it kept things interesting enough to not make me say '♥♥♥♥ you' and turn it off. Well, the dialogue almost did, but the story made up for that.

I love a story that puts its protagonists through the ringer, beats them up emotionally, and forces merciless ethical choices upon them.  This is such a story.  It has excellent, well realised characters, very good writing and pacing, and enough hatred and degredation to keep you reading on, you filthy voyeur of suffering.\n\nPlayable in about two hours, with multiple endings.  Begins with terrible tragedy, and gets better as you progress.  Like a bad detective novel, it'll drag you in and leave you absolutely satisfied by the time it's done with you.  You have no reason not to pick this up.

Was overall quite an interesting visual novel with unique aspects. Haven't gotten around to the second game in the series at the time I wrote this post, so my review is based on only this first one and what I've completed of it thus far.

Graphics: 8.5/10
For a low priced VN (9.99) the graphics were pretty amazing. I wasn't expecting the graphics to be were they were, so it was very nice to be surprised by this.

Gameplay: 8/10
Probably one of the most interesting things about this VN. It is a VN, so don't expect 3D action, but man were some of the puzzles and choices intruiging. The puzzles were not hard, but not necessarily easy. One of them even gives an alternate ending, which is interesting. I also like the computer aspect where you have to type in the information via the keyboard. Over-all. it was an interesting style and I would love to see more styles like this.

Characters: 7.5/10
The characters were also quite interesting. Both girls had their own unique personality, making you either hate or like them (I liked both personally). The design for both of them were also nicely done, adding more to the uniqueness of them. I didn't rate an 8 due to the fact that only one of the 2 had a in-depth background while the other was given some, but nowhere near as much as the other. (Might change after getting rest of trophies)

Story: 7.5/10
The story was really, I mean really. interesting. It took place in a spaceship out in space. You have a possibility to end up with 1 of 2 girls (or both if you get the harem ending) or obtain the bad ending. This much is common in most VNs, but the uniqueness of this one is the files and history. Both the files and certain options you make will give detailed information about the past of the game's story. Then there's the fact that the story of the second game is determined by what ending you got in the first one, a little twist not seen in most. Put simply, a wonderfuly (but short) storyline with interesting twists.

Over-All: 8/10
I would most certainly recommend this to both begginers and advanced VN readers.  =(^,.,^)=

For those not familiar with them, this game is a visual novel.  There's not much action and everything is about telling the story.  Your decisions effect where the story ends up.  The mechanics are a bit different than other visual novels.  You're in the future studying the logs of a Korean generational ship trying to find out how everyone on it died.  You find this information with the aid of two AIs via reading the ships logs and it covers a couple of different stories, some connected directly, some indirectly.   The game" such as it is doesn't take long to complete as can be told by my relatively short playtime.  I've acquired two of the endings.  One good one and one bad one.  There are others that I intend to go and get.  The story itself is actually quite good.  Fair warning that it's a sad one and there's no way to make it happy.  Bittersweet is about the best you can get out of the ending.  I really can't give many more details without blowing it.  Also there's a minigame of sorts involving using commands in an old command prompt style terminal part way through the game and it is timed(although they do give you a generous time allotment to do so) so be ready for that when it comes up.  Some people will probably dislike that part of the game but it honestly adds a lot of flavor to the whole game as it also forces some of the important decisions you had to make.   If you like the visual novel genre this game is a must buy.  If you're not sure how you feel about it
date: this is a good game to test the waters with."

reviewText:
Now, first of all, let me get one thing out of the way. This is more a visual novel than it is a game - which means, it is about reading things, imagining things, and talking to characters in a usually pretty linear and uninteractive fashion. Analogue is in this regard pretty innovative, since it is highly non-linear - it lets you decide which documents to read - to some extend, that is.
However, it's not just reading that you do, and I don't want to spoiler too much in this regard.
The two characters you talk to, namely the AIs Hyun-ae and Mute, are written in a very understandable and non-artificial fashion (despite being AI constructs). It is very nice to see that the author refrained from using many of the long-standing archetypes that are commonly involved in nowadays VNs - which makes it all the better.

Overall, I would say - if you like VNs, buy this game.
I love this and everything else Christina Love has made.
Well written, touching, gruesome and important. Comes highly recommended if you like good writing in games or read sci-fi authors like Ursula K. LeGuin.

Tl;dr If you enjoy reading or don't mind it this is an interesting game, not for everyone but it is enjoyable. Pick it up if you see it on sale.

Review (Very light on spoilers)

Story
The story without spoiling much is that you travel to one of the first space colony ships that has broken down and is just floating around in space. Your job is to download the datalogs to find out what happened to it.

Gameplay
A lot of reading through log dates, while interesting can put a lot of players off. It has some minimal dialouge choices with the characters you talk with that does impact your ending. Imagine if you read a book and once in a while a friend pops in to ask your opinion on what you read.

Music
The music is fitting even if it does leave some desire for more. As standalone music I would listen to it while drawing for example. A cake that could have used the cherry on top.

Art
The game gets a lot of points here, while simple in design they look rather good and while the animation is on the simplistic side that's not the focus of the game. The focus of the game is on the beckground story and the story of the characters you meet.
Made me feel things.\nI don't normally feel things.\n9/10, worth every penny
Great game if you love reading and story over gameplay.

A solid story with a solid interface. You really do feel that you're in your assigned role of the story, given the tools needed to do exactly what you must. The plot feels very realistic and leaves you questioning details of the timeline. Easy enough for anyone to progress through, yet offering enough challenge for those looking for it, this game suits the tastes of many players.

My favorite things were the story, the interface, and the ease of saving/loading your game. Thanks to that feature, it is very easy to redo a question or choice in case you make a mistake.

My only complaint is that the game is very short. I would have loved to hear another perspective with the addition of a character, but that is completely on my side. It goes to show you that I just wanted more of this game!

Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone.
*Hyun-Ae scares me.

An engaging interactive story. Plot is reminiscent of Taiwanese/Korean period dramas.

Characterisation of the main roles are almost immaculately conceived as with their individual motivations; the ending moments being quite hard-hitting. Note that the tale does include somewhat explicit/graphic descriptions at certain points.

A successful playthrough should last around 2-3 hours and much of the gameplay primarily involves heavy reading. The title also involves understanding of a pseudo command prompt that is not particularly too obtuse to grasp for most players.

Be sure to also download and try out a free copy of the developer's previous work, Digital: A Love Story.

In every Sci-fi RPG, there will always be a level where you find yourself in some sort of abandoned mining colony/research facility/space ship/whatever, and as you explore it, there will inevitably be a collection of logs made by the people who lived there that allow you so slowly piece together what happened and why nobody is alive anymore. This is basically that experience in its own standalone game.

Pros:
-The writing is absolutely amazing, the story couldn’t be better.
-Despite being a visual novel, a genre notorious for having very little gameplay, Analog manages to link story and gameplay in a way I’ve never seen in a VN

Cons:
-The story is incredibly complex is a plethora of characters, I had to use physical notes to keep track of what everybody was and what happened with each of them
-The gameplay can be quite unforgiven at times, for example, the object of the game is to unlock all the documents, and the way you do this is by asking one of the AIs their opinion on a document, and sometimes they’ll give you another one, but one of the first four documents you start with, if you ask the AIs’ thoughts on it, she’ll take it away, and there will be no way to get it back without restarting the game!
An amazing experience for VN newbies. Still pretty damn good for vets as well. I definitely recommend this for any VN fan.
Really good interactive novel story.

I'm new to this visual novel thing, but I liked this game for loads of reasons.

Pros:First being how the story is paced via logs I thought that was a strong point reading something then reading something else that puts the story together light a giant intricate puzzle.  The second reason is the actual story I enjoyed reading it but that's 100% my opinion and yours could be completely different. I also liked the personalities of the AI and the mystery that surrounds you with your lack of knowledge.For the third and final reason, I enjoy the flexibility of the the story, there is lots of different paths for you to follow questions to ask and etc.

Cons:For the cons I think for some it might be a little difficult to understand with all the stories all over the place. There will also be a problem if you don't enjoy reading at all. It is a little short but there is a sequel so, yeah.

Overall is it worth 10$, me yes, but it's all about your personality and what you like in the end. 8/10

This game is incredible.  First off, I'd like to mention that it isn't a traditional game.  It's a sort of mystery about an ancient spaceship.  You learn about what happened to the civilization by reading fragments of logs left behind and by interacting with the AI you meet at the start of the game.  The writing is incredible and I think anyone with a sufficiently open mind shiould play it.  If you have played other visual novels, I can safely say this is the most engrossing and maturally written one I've come across.  It is easily worth the full asking price and there are multiple endings to find.

This game demands your time. This game wants you to read a lot of text and dress up cute anime girls in dresses. IT also has multiple endings and interesting subject matter. If you liked Digital: A Love Story, you'll love this game.

reviewText: Trust me. Give it a try.

A fascinating take on Visual Novels using a surprising, yet brilliant, interface with an equally surprising, yet brilliant, setting.  Quirky and memorable characters, a very well written story, and a plot that unravels in multiple ways for multiple playthroughs. (On a side note, checkout Digital: A Love Story, another VN made by Christina Love)

I was sceptical at first, but after trying out the demo I was hooked. Don't be fooled by the minimal interface or anime-style characters if either bother you - this game has a story to tell and does it in a gripping way, breaking elements into bite-size chunks that make you beg for more.\nAfter playing the demo for its full length, I bought the game at full-price and continued to complete it in one sitting. For an entirely narrative-based game, a good 3 hours of gripping gameplay is quite a feat, and with only half the content unlocked and plenty more endings to see, there's a lot of space for replayability! Concept art prizes for completion percentage, too!\nAll I can say is 'give the demo a try'. You'll probably either love it or hate it, but I certainly loved it. This game hit all the right spots at the right times, emotionally connected me with a character, strained that trust, then ultimately rewarded both her and I with catharsis. Worth every penny I paid.

Really well done visual novel exploring the remaining logs and conversing with the AI systems on a generation ship far into the future. I played through most of it in the course of the three and a half hour train ride on the way back from PAX, so I could play Hate Plus as well.\n\nAt one point I had figured out the emotional gut punch but it still delivered, not easily dodged. Unless you require the slaying of zombies by the hundredfold in your games, get this one.

Very interesting concept of a game. Revovles around a spaceship lost to time, and you have to get records that showed what happened to the ship that left two AI's in control, with the whole crew dead. Strangely, this is set up more like a JRPG Dating sim in that you have to confer with the two of them on topics ranging from sex to murder, leading to some....interesting conversations.\n\nIf you don't mind reading a lot, the story is actually pretty well written, and the dialouge (Besides some of the love parts) are pretty well written. Worth the few bucks.

Remote accessing the direlect's central computer, you meet two AI who help you navigate the logs, left behind by the long deceased crew.

After some time they released Hate Plus, a spinoff from Analogue. Both are great games. I recommend them if you love visual novels, aren't Japanese but worth.

Personal rating: 8/10

This game is a visual novel.  If you have no idea what a visual novel is, it is essentially a Japanese-style porn game without the porn.  What you have left is a heaping supply of writing, well-translated from Korean, and a mystery that you can uncover by reading it all.

There's some game elements to it in that what you read can be shown to your AI companion to unlock more things to read.  Plus a pseudo terminal in which you type in commands that will help you unlock more things to read.

There's not much game here and you're better off with the far more fascinating predecessor which is free on the Internet.  The predecessor is called Digital: A Love Story (and it will remind you why dialing into BBS systems was a ♥♥♥♥♥).

Ultimately, there's not much here, but it can be an interesting distraction for those who like art games like Dear Esther or Home.  This game is not like either of them.

I think it is the only game I have ever got all the achievements for, so it is not a long or difficult game to complete...unless reading emails is a problem in which case I would advise against it as that is pretty much all there is to the game.

The console parts were a throwback to my days trying to get dos games to run on a PC that couldn't really handle them - curse you nostalgia!

I don't regret buying or playing it but it is not for everyone.

If you don't like reading, then this isn't the game for you.

But if you're the kind of person who, when they're playing any other sort of video game likes to read all the optional journal entries and log files of the departed denizens of whatever ruin you're slicin' up monsters in, then you'll find this a pleasant surprise.

The visual novel format does much to immerse you inside the game's world--you're not just a guy reading a book, you're a guy on a spaceship drifting next to an abandoned hulk reading the ship's logs about a doomed voyage while two AIs who aren't telling you the whole story comment on them.

It's not anime". It's a story about politics
recommended: and inhumanity. It's one of the first "visual novels" to remember that the word "novel" is there for a reason."

After getting 95% of the way through this game in one sitting, with 4/5 endings unlocked (god damn harems!), I have to fully recommend this game.

I've never played a VN quite like this. Whilst trying to retrieve data on a space mission, you meet two AI girls with very different viewpoints on the situation you slowly uncover. The interface is slick, but with the addition of the console window (that plays a very important role!) is something completely out of the blue. The intertwining accounts from various points of view all build an amazing, interesting, and sometimes very hot story.

If you just like to have the story play out for you, with only a few choices, then this isn't the game for you. If you're looking for something with the right amount of story and interactive gameplay (without stat building!) then I highly recommend Analogue.

Outstanding, but disturbing, visual novel.  A 22nd-century space archeologist investigates the abandoned hulk of a Korean generation ship.  Searching through the diaries/logs of the ship's inhabitants yields a twisted story of brutal familial politics, social castes, and gender inequity, inspired by the medieval Joseon Dynasty.
