I don’t usually enjoy these types of games, but I liked this one. It’s sort of like an interactive mystery novel with pictures (be prepared fod for a lot of reading). The reason I liked it is because the story is, shockingly, pretty interesting. It also introduces enough game elements to prevent it from being nothing more than a pure text adventure and the length is just right.

You play the part of a salvager who is trying to uncover what happened on a derelict generation ship, which is one of the theorized ways humans might be able to explore the galaxy. The way this story goes is how I think such an attempt would end in real life, too (I’ll stop here before revealing any spoilers).

There are different levels of depth to be discovered to the story as well as multiple endings. What you uncover depends on what questions you ask and how deep you dig. The game is also timed, in a way, so that after a certain point certain endings become impossible depending on what you’ve done so far. Thankfully, the game’s length is paced excellently so right around the time you are getting tired of reading the text, you’ll find yourself near the end. You’re also able to speed through much of the text on subsequent playthroughs to see different endings, which is nice.

I liked the music a lot, too. It sets a very appropriate mood throughout the story. I played this with headphones on and I’d recommend that. It greatly increases the immersive feel as this game is best enjoyed with a couple of hours blocked out and no distractions to take you away from it, not unlike reading a book.

Is it worth $10, though? That’s a tough call and will depend on just how much you like this sort of thing. It will only take you 2-3 hours to get through this and considerably less to view the alternate endings, if you even care about doing that. And once you beat it, there is little reason to play through it again. I bought it during a Steam sale, though, and am content with what I paid for it.

I will say that the music and writing are above average and the artwork is well done. This is essentially an adventure game that removes all of the pointing & clicking and walking around aimlessly through the same maps. To me, that is a good thing.

This is a VN which is in a unusual format. I would recommend it for the sole purpose of experiencing the format. It's a mediocre game, but a enjoyable one. I don't recommend this game for people who do not enjoy reading and cross referencing, as it will be very tedious for people that prefer action formats.

A Visual Novel on Steam!  If you are interested in darker stories and approaching said story from multiple perspectives this is a solid choice.  Multiple playthroughs are required to really experience this game, and that is a definite plus.  It also has a very enjoyable soundtrack I might add!  While it is a visual novel I think it is worth checking out even if that isn't a genre you find yourself famliar with or all that interested in.  If a demo run can't convince you, perhaps you should hunt down Digital: A Love Story and give that a swing.  If you like that, come back here, and buy Analogue: A Hate Story.  'Nuff said.

This was the first visual novel that I ever played and I had no idea what was waiting for me. An intense and great story, that's what! Presenting it as a video game (going with a very lax definition of game" here) made it far more gripping and impactful than it would have been as a book. This is how interactive storytelling needs to be used! I am certain that the very unusual gameplay of this genre and the anime look of the characters won't appeal to everyone though."
Very interesting,

This game is a great storytelling experience.
While innately simple, the game gives the player the role of slowly unveiling the mystery
surrounding a massive derelict colonial spacecraft, the Mugunghwa, set adrift
for almost a thousand years and all but forgotten by time,
using only the logs stored on the ship by it's former inhabitants
and the aid of the AI that reside within.

The game features a great soundtrack an intriguing and dark story dealing with moral ambiguity, transhumanism and loneliness with fleshed out characters
and high levels of character development

The game does fall into some traditions of the genre but manages to do so with care and without distorting the experience.

A definate buy for fans of light novels and beyond.

A stunningly hard hitting text adventure.   Slow to start, and a little bit of roughness around the edges, but beautifully told and absolutely worth picking up.

If you don't care for visual novels, or if you don't like to read at all, then don't bother. Otherwise, Analogue: A Hate Story is definitely worth getting.

A term worth knowing:
- Mugunhwa : a spacecraft of some sort that carried an entire colony for the purpose of... well, colonization, I guess.

Gameplay:
It's a novel. You click. Don't be stupid.

Plot(?):
The story itself is presented through files unlocked by interacting with both *Hyun-ae and *Mute. From the ambiguous degredation of the culture in the Mugunghwa [from modern values to that of a more patriarchal -or medieval- culture], to the relationships between the people involved within the ship, Analogue is very well written.

Characters:
*Hyun-ae and *Mute are pretty much opposites: *Hyun-ae being a more contemporary female whereas *Mute behaves like an old-fashioned one, albeit a little angry. They are both likeable in their own ways, ways that you'll see if you buy this.

Conclusion:
Get it.
10/10 would play again

Christina Vee is probably the best writer of visual novels in the English-speaking world, and Analogue continues that tradition via an engaging and thought-provoking storyline, delivered in an extremely immersive fashion. I strongly this (and it's spiritual predecessor, Digital: A Love Story" to anyone interested in the genre."

I can't say I'm much more visual novels, or that I've really had much experience with them outside the two I've read/played by Christinia Love (Digital: A Love Story, being the first one I read/played.)
And, well, I definitely would say to look into Digital: A Love Story since it's freeware and it's a very interesting execution of a visual novel that makes it feel much less like the very very tiny bit of other visual novels I've tried. It's also a bit more accesible than Analogue: A Hate Story, so in general it's a good place to start to see if you even like Love's style before spending money on a more involved and intense story.

Now, when I say Digital has a interesting execution, that isn't to say Analogue doesn't. It is similar in many ways, but it's different - which is good, really. The interface of both games fits the story and setting. Analogue does feel more like a visual novel, though. But probably because it's longer and there is quite a bit more reading. However, it's a complex story, and told in a way that is engaging. It also manages to deal with many serious themes. Patriatrcy, sexism, sexuality -- to name a few.

So, try Digital: A Love Story and if you like it, then chances this is a game for you (mind you, this is... well it is called A Hate Story"). Or

Analogue : A Hate Story and its sequel Hate Plus are both excellent. If you like to read good stories, this one is complex and far from being manichean.

The whole scenario is really good and your choices (and how you define yourself as the main character) will have some serious consequences.

If you prefer action packed games and/or do not like dramatic or tragic stories, go your way...

The metacritic score should not be seen as a ranking of the quality of this game, but instead as an indicator that Analogue is a different kind of game that may not readily appeal to pimple-faced FPS addicts. The writing isn't Hemingway or M. H. Kingston, but is convincing. If you take the time to read everything, you'll likely be drawn into the story.

Even so, the game isn't preachy. You are fully free to be a chauvinistic creep if you want. I'd say this is the best textual interactive fiction game I've ever played, and perhaps the best of anything that calls itself interactive fiction either way.

So bottom line, if you love sci-fi, psychology, thinking about relationships and emotions, and reading, you'll likely love this game. If you hate to read, the game is not for you.
Something different.  If you like reading then this is definitely worth trying out.

Hyun-ae, do I love thee, oh let me count the ways...
Analogue doesn't quite fit 'visual novel' as a category, but that's the closest name we've got. Because what Analogue really is, is a multi-faceted adventure story that you, the protaganist, can only read about - except of course, when it comes to life around you in the form of a ship's AI who was there at the time. The two AI, Hyun-ae and Mute, are gorgeous in their differences, and humorous in comparison, one showing somethings while hiding others and vice versa. And it's a good thing you've got these two (ONLY two? In a VN? But but... yeah. This is no ero story :P) chirpy and/or eager-to-please starbabes to guide you through the diaries of  the Mugungwe's last days because... Everyone will read something different into the historical world created, into the character of the Pale Bride, and into how everything comes to a conclusion. I, for one, fell helplessly in love with a fake AI in a game... so there's that.

However you choose to enjoy the game, as an explorer, as a route seeker, as a completionist, there are hours of... entertainment, I won't always say enjoyment. Some messages are uncomfortable to hear and Christina Love does, once again, a wonderful job of giving us a rude awakening to things we might rather ignore.

Read like a novel, this is harrowing and heartfelt. Read in role-play, truly reacting to and feeling with Hyun-ae... it'll darn near break your heart. All the recommends.

Now, there are a lot of reviews floating around complaining about how the game 'doesn't feel like a visual novel', or asking why there are only so many 'routes' and 'endings'. Those people are, I think, completely missing the point of Analogue: A Hate Story. It's not a dating sim. Sure, there are elements of that format, and you do have the ability to manipulate the story somewhat through your responses. However, this game is more of a visual novel in the purest sense: it invites you to uncover a story. Apparently there's 59,000 words of text in this game, so if you're feeling unfulfilled by finishing subsequent playthroughs within ten minutes like one of the top-rated negative reviewers, you're doing it wrong.\n\nTo be fair, Analogue is a short game. There's not a huge amount to it, and it doesn't take a significant time investment to complete. However, what is there is charming and thought-provoking, with a surprisingly interesting - if slightly two-dimensional - story to be dug through. I'm sure if you were to put the game into Skip Mode, you probably could get the best ending in ten minutes, but you'd be totally missing the point. Experience this game as if it were a book, for after all, that is what a good visual novel is intended to emulate.

I don't have much experience with this type of game. I have played a few like it but most were free online games that were not very good. Picked this game up on a steam sale and it has gotten me interested in this genre. The gameplay is pretty much reading through letters and journal entries,  trying to understand what caused the death of the ships inhabitants. The best part of the game to me would be the two A.I. programs, the soundtrack, and the way you interact with the game.

The game introduces you to the two A.I.s and they are fun to be with. Sure they play up to some stereotypes and some people will get upset that the choices you make with them basically boil down to being nice or being rude with no gray area. I like this because if the relationships in the game were as complicated as real life then it would be frustrating. The two A.I.s are fun enough to listien to and interact with. I did not find a single time that I found myself wishing that they would shut up (though to be fair I only went through the game once and so have limited experince with one of the A.I.s.) The tedium of reading letters and journal entries are broken up by showing the letters to the A.I.s and getting their view of it which can be radically different depending who you show it to. This fleshes out the story while allowing you to get to know the A.I.

The soundtrack of the game is fun to listen to. It re-enforces the space theme of the game and changes at some of the more important parts. I can't say much more about the soundtrack since I am a pleb with little knowledge of music. All I can say is that I love music from video games that I can listen to in the backround and this serves that purpose. It is a soundtrack that I do plan on buying.

Finally I enjoy the way that you interact in the game. You start the game at a computer terminal, typing in commands. The rest of the game is spent going through screens, reading journals and interacting much the same way you would if it was actually your computer. I have not played a lot of games that used this set up so it may just be the novelty speaking but I felt less disconnected from the game than other games I have played in the similar vein (again, a very small pool.) The computer interface is used very effectively about half-way through the game in a way that was loads of fun.

Overall I really enjoyed this game. Is it worth 10$? I can't answer that because I bought it for less and am new to the genre and don't know the average cost of these games. I enjoyed it and if you can get it on a steam sell I would suggest you do. I had fun and there is some replay value with the multiple endings. So to me it was worth it and I might pick up the sequel at full price with the soundtrack.

reviewText:
If you don't care for visual novels, or if you don't like to read at all, then don't bother. Otherwise, Analogue: A Hate Story is definitely worth getting.

A term worth knowing:
- Mugunhwa : a spacecraft of some sort that carried an entire colony for the purpose of... well, colonization, I guess.

Gameplay:
It's a novel. You click. Don't be stupid.

Plot(?):
The story itself is presented through files unlocked by interacting with both *Hyun-ae and *Mute. From the ambiguous degredation of the culture in the Mugunghwa [from modern values to that of a more patriarchal -or medieval- culture], to the relationships between the people involved within the ship, Analogue is very well written.

Characters:
*Hyun-ae and *Mute are pretty much opposites: *Hyun-ae being a more contemporary female whereas *Mute behaves like an old-fashioned one, albeit a little angry. They are both likeable in their own ways, ways that you'll see if you buy this.

Conclusion:
Get it.
10/10 would play again

Christine Love's best game yet. If you're unfamiliar with her, and uncomfortable about dropping $10 on an unknown quantity (especially a product that's pretty much just a visual novel), I'd recommend checking out her first two games:

Digital: A Love Story - http://scoutshonour.com/digital/

Don't Take It Personally, Babe.. - http://scoutshonour.com/donttakeitpersonallybabeitjustaintyourstory/

Both are free.

Do not judge this game by it's style, as I'm sure some will. Analogue has some of the best damned writing I've seen in a game and will subvert your expectations. It's an overlooked game that is ridiculous brilliant and deserves far more attention. Do yourself a favor and buy it, and the upcoming sequel, Hate Plus.

reviewText: A strong Visual Novel, with good replay value and the interesting addition of a command line interface for certain actions. You can essentially get the entire story from either AI's viewpoint, depending on what choices you make. Once you've reached the end, there will absolutely be pieces of the story that you didn't see the first time, and entirely new scenes that you can find by replaying it. If you're looking to pick up all the achievements, that will keep you playing through a few more times -- and it was still fun all the way to the end.

This was an interesting, thought provoking story. I enjoyed the historical references to Korea, and the unique take on how to display it. Fun, witty, and a little bit flirty, the story is a good mystery, and you're there to solve it.

Analogue: A Hate Story is simply put one of the most impressive visual novels ever to come from a Western developer. It is an emotional roller-coaster from start to finish that swings everywhere between playful fun and horrified disbelief.

It is hard to summarise the story without spoiling anything, but I'll try doing so by saying that it's a story about the devolution of society as we know it now into complete and utter patriarchy where the women themselves believe that their rightful place is in the service of their husbands. The only exception to that is our heroine who provides most of dialogue and commentary on the individual files.

Speaking of files (and correspondence), those are the primary narrative tool that Christine Love employed to tell the story. That is perhaps the most unique aspect of Analogue, when it comes to the storytelling. Instead of exposition through dialogue, which is the most typical form of exposition in visual novels, we are greeted by a wonderful system which makes the game feel more like a literary work when compared to its run-of-the-mill counterparts and allows you to form your own opinion on the matter, rather than forcing that of the characters on you. Dialogue of course is in the game, but the amount of characters is minimal and they mostly provide commentary in which they express their own personal stance on the situation explored in the entry.

The file system, though, was also the source of my biggest problem with the game. It may be due to my own incompetence, but I did manage to get myself stuck at a point where I was clueless as to how to gain access to the rest of the files, which was also the reason why I had the game sitting on my hard drive for months only 2/3 finished, because once I lost track of the story, it was a bit of a challenge to get myself back on track again. Today I finally gathered enough courage to try and get back on the story-train and I simply blitzed through it. The story left a deep impression in me and for those unsure about buying this game, yes, it was worth every penny.

PS: Can't wait to start finally playing Hate Plus!
PPS: Christine Love, your Twitter is one of the coolest places on the Internet!

Edit: Spelling

Like Christine Love's earlier game Digital: a Love Story, Analogue feels like a detective story while still conveying a very compelling message about society and human relationships. The game's simulated computer interface gives the player a sense of both power and isolation, but the limited flow of information leaves you wanting more of the story, even after reading a novel's worth of log entries.

Christine Love does very interesting games, although they're more like Interactive Fiction than a 'game' - she uses the medium to tell stories that wouldn't really be possible without them. Analogue is something of a companion story to Digital: A Love Story, one of her earlier works.\n\nI really like Analogue. It is simple and basically consists of a lot of reading with a few simple puzzles to spice things up. It won't be for everyone but, really, you should try this game. It's a solid story that really tugged at my heartstrings. And the music is quite good as well.

Make no mistake, this IS a visual novel, which implies that 90% of this will be reading.

In particular, 90% of this will be reading about gender politics and self destruction in neo-feudal korea.

Anyway, to the 5 people with steam accounts I didn't scare away, I find it is well-written thus far, and I would recommend a look to anyone with the patience.

This game is a great storytelling experience.
While innately simple, the game gives the player the role of slowly unveiling the mystery
surrounding a massive derelict colonial spacecraft, the Mugunghwa, set adrift
for almost a thousand years and all but forgotten by time,
using only the logs stored on the ship by it's former inhabitants
and the aid of the AI that reside within.

The game features a great soundtrack an intriguing and dark story dealing with moral ambiguity, transhumanism and loneliness with fleshed out characters
and high levels of character development

The game does fall into some traditions of the genre but manages to do so with care and without distorting the experience.

A definate buy for fans of light novels and beyond.

Analogue manages to tell multiple intersecting stories about the generation ship Mugunghwa.  The two characters you interact with are consistent and act as unreliable commentary on the lives of the passengers.  The interface is great as you never have to backtrack as everything is available to review.  The length of the game is reasonable considering that multiple playthroughs are really necessary to get a full understanding of the story.\nYou shouldn't expect a full romantic understanding of the characters though, as the main narrative focus is on world-building and understanding the environment on the ship.  The title for the game is apt, as you'll likely end up hating as much as loving by the end...

If you like reading walls of text and try to make sense of it, you won't go wrong with this game. I personally had a hard time understanding the story plots because it was just all a mess (they improved it a lot in the next game).

Honestly, I wasn't getting much out of the story at all; only the ones with the most important and interesting characters. This is because the way the game is structured; it's difficult to recognize characters, especially since they all have foreign names that, to my eyes, all look the same.

Once I completed the first story line, it was actually pretty dull to do the other ones for the achievments. Felt like a whole lotta grinding.

I'm only recommending this game for the story (and the sci-fi setting), not the gameplay. You'll want to play this before Hate Plus though, since the story is connected.

So, this game has two entry barriers:

1) You should be willing to spend most of the time playing this game reading walls of text.
2) You should feel comfortable typing commands into a unix-ish kind of interface.

If these two things aren't instant turnoffs for you, you might like this game.

reviewText: I've only played through it once so far, but I found it a satisfying experience. It was interesting how the story kinda pieced together slowly, and also how the only two characters you interact with have such different personalities.

Christine Love has made great stories in the past but this defintley takes the cake. Having some of the most indepth characters, fantastic music, and more philosophical themes than your body can handle, Analogue: A Hate Story is a story that will leave you intrigued to the very end...if you are an avid reader and like philosophical stuff.

Pros:

- The themes it deals with are some of the most unique and untouched upon subjects I have ever seen in any game to this date. Dealing with interpersonal relationships, LGBT, transhumanism, and loneliness. It certainly isn't cliche.
- Isaac Schankler is one of the most musically talented people I have ever had to pleasure to listen to. Buy the soundtrack, now.
- Other things that would delve into spoilers.

Cons:

- If you're not a person that reads books often, prepare yourself for a problem. See, Analogue isn't a traditonal visual novel focused around dialogue and art. No, it's more minimalist. Being next to only text. It's litreally wall after wall of text. This isn't a bad thing, but if you're not an avid reader it will be daunting at best.
- Not an ideal entry point as your first visual novel, no I have better things for that.
- Could've been maybe just a tiny bit longer.
Only buy if you like reading, I enjoyed it. Still not much gameplay, make sure you read up on this one before committing to buying it. Again, I enjoyed it, not everyone else might.

reviewText: There's a grotesquely misplaced anime dating experience in here, offsetting an otherwise well-written violent tragedy.  Good on the whole if you have a lead stomach.

I was so happy when I found Analogue: A Hate Story on Steam, I had played the game earlier and totally loved it. Christine Love manages to draw you in to her story and her futuristic science fiction world and you will be stuck for hours. It reminded me of those choose-your-own adventure stories from childhood and for a moment I really felt like a space traveller that had found a great and unknown ship. The interface is simple but beautiful and the characters are complex and interesting.

In short version: a great game with breathtakingly awesome storyline and characters, all thanks to Christine Love. Those who like anime will love this game!\nAnalogue: A Hate Story will also include some portions of the Korean culture and how things were in the early days of it, as you progress through the game. The story of this game is non-linear, so it's up to you and your actions to decide, how the game will end, since the game has at least five endings.

Disclaimer: If you're the kind of person who doesn't like visual novels and thinks that they shouldn't be on Steam for whatever reason, you can leave now. If, instead, you're interested in this sort of thing or is willing to try something different out, read on.

Now, with that out of the way, WOW is Analogue good. Probably one of the best things I've tried out on Steam recently! It's about you, a space investigator, attempting to find out what happened to a ruined spaceship (the Mugunghwa). A simple premise, but the execution is amazing.

To start off, let's talk about the presentation. The entire story is told through old logs written by the ship's inhabitants, as well as conversations with its AIs (*Hyun-ae and *Mute), and all of this is seen through a single computer interface. Again, it's simple, but it works perfectly while also being quite unusual, so I really liked it. It does a very good job at delivering the plot and setting by simultaneously giving you a lot of information while also allowing your imagination to put everything together by itself.

And speaking of the setting, that's where Analogue truly shines! First off, it's based on Korean culture, which is... not something that you see very often (if at all), so it's refreshing to have something like this. Second, I really appreciate the research that was put into it. As the author explains in the bibliography, society aboard the Mugunghwa was based on a certain period of Korean history, and knowing that things like this actually DID happen at some point in history adds so much more weight to the story, as well as having the secondary benefit of making it educative without feeling forced.

But what about the story, huh? There's no easy way of explaining it properly, but it's a wild ride. The horrible things detailed in some of the logs really leave an impression on you (sup Block 1), but you also have things such as *Hyun-ae dressing up in a maid outfit and being adorable or *Mute being tsundere, and the contrast between the serious and easygoing parts causes both to be even more impactful. In addition, though the narrative is mostly direct, it still sometimes leaves little hints about certain things here and there, so that you can put everything together in your head before seeing it explained in a log or something, and it's great.

Other things to talk about... the art, while not the best, is still pretty good, and does its job well. Same goes for the music, pretty much. And I really enjoyed that one puzzle involving the reactor and a command-line interface.

But of course, Analogue is not without faults, and I find that most of those can be found in its technical side. It's annoying how you need to wait a second for buttons to work after you change pages, and there are some problems involving event flags, such as the one involving decrypting Block 3... but really, those things are pretty much insignificant in the grand scheme of things, not managing to be anything more than annoyances.

Bottom line: if you don't mind reading a lot and is interested in learning something about Korean history, definitely give Analogue a try. I certainly didn't expect it to be as good as it turned out to be.

This game gets a lot of unneeded flak, and I can see why: the visual novel genre isn't for everyone. At its core, this game is basically a novel that has a pretty interface and an interactive narrator, that once you read everything available, you have to do a little bit of thinking and some work to get to the next part. There are also some REALLY clever puzzles in this game, including one that involves creating a paradox to achieve an ending that would otherwise be impossible.

If the words Ever17, Corpse Party, Collage, and 999 conjure positive images for you, then you will love this game.

If you've never played a Visual Novel before, there's a demo.

As for me, I think Steam needs to get some more Visual Novels.

Awesome game. I'm loving to see that there are more and more of these visual novel style games popping up on steam. There are just some times when I want to play a game, but don't want to play it necessarily for the challenge. I just want to be told a good story and have an influence on it, like a choose your own adventure book.

The Good: Good story that becomes a great story. I loved the two main characters. They both had their own personality and beliefs. They were very deep charcters, but we also got to see why they were the way they were. The game is mainly played from reading diary entries from the ship's crew. Through that you gain insight on what happened on it. You spend a little bit of the game in a DOS style console. It's not hard or as complex as DOS though. Both the message reading system and DOS part of the game are really well done.

The Bad: The only small nitpick I have with the game is that it was hard for me to keep up with the characters with no sort of way to just click a name and have their bio pop up (or at least what I know about them so far). There isn't really any bad parts to this game unless you don't like reading or you want something with a little more interaction like you'd get from another genre.

The Ugly: N/A No bugs, no crashes, just a clean game.

Summary: If you like to read and you want a good story buy this. If you like this buy Hate Plus as well. It puts a nice bit of icing on the cake to complete the already awesome story.

It's a Visual Novel with text based directives, and holds a prfound story no matter your choices (minus downloading everything from the getgo or killing yourself). The story is extremely dark with only the 2 interactable and loveable characters to lighten the mood that this burdens the reader with. It's a harsh and realitsic story of how ♥♥♥♥ goes wrong. It's not for the faint of heart or of the younger age as this gets very explicit at the end (very graphic mention of lesbian ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and intercourse). In general its a great story, an excellent food for thought and how we take what have for granted. Also you may enjoy copius amounts of cosplay" or all the potienally laughable gender-confusion related "deres". reviewText: One of the best interactive story games I have ever played!\n\n

Christine Love builds an amazing dystopian space detective story with two lovely AI characters that really get inside your head.  There are dialogue choices to be made to break up the investigation and parts of the game become very socially intiment as you have questions presented to you that ask how much you are part of the problem or how much you are willing to forgive.  Yes, the game is essentially nothing but reading datalogs and talking to AI but if you love detective stories then you'll be enthralled by the search that you need to put into the game to find all the clues to put together what exactly happened to this ship.  The truth is pretty messed up.
There is a lot of reading to this, and not much of an ending.. but that would be missing the point. Part dating sim, part space mystery, this is a neat little visual novella game.

I usually hate these kinds of adventures.  Thanks to some clever writing, an engaging story, and a neat little bit of hacking required halfway through the game, you're dragged back into the story way after you should've gone to bed!  It plays a little too much like a dating sim after you solve the mystery at the end, but aside from this small nitpick the rest of the game is brilliant.  I finished it in about six hours, but that's probably because I was taking notes to follow the story as you go back and forth  through email logs of the long dead crew with the help of a slightly mental AI.  I have to say the ending saddened me, although I tend to feel empathy towards the characters I interact with in good games, and this definitely qualifies.

Very well written, and has some intriguing game concepts in regards to how you can make a Virtual Novel more interactive.  Imagine reading a book and having to coax the writer to reveal more of the true story!  Impossible for fiction, but in a game/VN it fits perfectly.  It took me two hours to finish and I imagine if I wanted to see all the endings and extras (the game keeps track of all em), it would take me an additional hour and a half.
One of the best visual novels I've played in recent times. I'm gonna be shooting for 100% in it, even though there are parts I don't understand how to beat.
Surprisingly in depth and touching storyline with a hint of sadness and severe sexism experienced with the characters within the story.... Well done to the makers!
